newsitem.title: USA: U.S. mortgage-backeds mostly flat, seek direction.
newsitem.headline: U.S. mortgage-backeds mostly flat, seek direction.

text.p: U.S. mortgage-backed securities were largely flat on Tuesday, mostly tracking their Treasury counterparts.
Mortgage experts said that overall, trading was fairly thin amid a quiet afternoon session. Investors were awaiting Wednesday's release of the February consumer price index (CPI), they said.
"We'll see if CPI confirms or denies (producer prices) from last Friday," one trader said. "Other than that, there will be a lot of sitting and waiting," he said.
A market-friendly CPI should keep spreads to Treasuries in a narrow range, said traders.
"We probably will not widen unless something drastic happens in our market," one trader said.

However, if consumer prices show a much stronger-than-expected reading, spreads might widen in anticipation of an upward move in short-term interest rates at next Tuesday's Federal Open Market Committee meeting, he said.
In key coupons, Ginnie Mae 30-year 7.5 percent paper was unchanged at 99-02/32, yielding 94 basis points over the 10-year Treasury note.
Comparable Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac issues were unchanged as well, at 99-04/32 and 99-10/32, respectively.
The 10-year Treasury note was also unchanged at 96-21/32 to yield 6.72 percent.

The February CPI, due Wednesday at 0830 EST/1330 GMT, is expected on average to have advanced a moderate 0.2 percent after a 0.1 percent increase in January, according to a Reuters poll of U.S. economists.
